raw_text:
Further rise in UK jobless total
 
 The UK's jobless total rose for the second month in a row in December, official figures show.
 
 The number of people out of work rose 32,000 to 1.41 million in the last three months of 2004, even as 90,000 more people were in employment. Average earnings rose by 4.3% in the year to December up from November's 4.2%, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) added. Meanwhile, the benefit claimant total fell 11,000 to 813,200 last month. Throughout 2004, the number of people in work increased by 296,000 to 28.52 million - the highest figure since records began in 1971.
 
 The apparent discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economically inactive. While the UK's jobless rate rose to 4.7% from 4.6% in the previous quarter, the rate still remains one of the lowest in the world, compared with 12.1% in Germany, 10.4% in Spain and 9.7% in France. But, despite more people being in work, the manufacturing sector continued to suffer, with 104,000 workers axed during the last quarter of 2004 - pushing employment in the sector to a record low of 3.24 million by the end of last year. The figures prompted some analysts to forecast that the Bank of England will almost certainly raise rates this year. Marc Ostwald, a strategist at Monument Securities told Reuters that while no immediate market impact could be expected, "it is enough to underline that they (the BoE) will be more hawkish on rates".
llama3.2:1b: The UK's jobless total rose by 32,000 in December to 1.41 million, with a record increase of 296,000 in work in 2004.
The jobless rate was 4.7% compared to 4.6% in the previous quarter.
The manufacturing sector suffered an additional 104,000 workers being axed during the year, pushing employment to a record low.
llama3.2:3b: The UK's jobless total rose 32,000 to 1.41 million in the last quarter of 2004, but this was offset by a rise of 90,000 in employment, bringing the total number of people in work to 28.52 million - a record high since 1971.
gemma2:2b: The UK's jobless total rose in December, but employment numbers increased as well.
Average earnings grew and the benefit claimant count fell.
Despite this, manufacturing job losses continued and economic inactivity decreased.
Analysts predict the Bank of England may raise interest rates soon due to these factors.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The UK's jobless rate rose for the second month in a row in December.
It has risen 320,000 people since November, and there were 813,200 claimants to benefit payments last month.
The working population increased by 296,000 compared with the previous quarter, but fewer people were economically inactive during the same period.
This led to more people being in work than before.
However, despite this, employment levels fell as more workers left their jobs and factories closed down.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK's jobless total rose in December for the second month running, with 32,000 people added and employment increasing by 90,000.

Average earnings rose slightly but less than expected; while unemployment fell from record lows compared to Germany, Spain, France, and some analysts predict an upcoming interest rate hike due to rising jobless numbers.
qwen2.5:3b: UK jobless total rose by 32,000 in December to reach 1.41 million, despite an increase of 90,000 in employment.
The benefit claimant total fell by 11,000.
Overall, the number of people in work reached a record high of 28.52 million.
Despite these figures, unemployment rate rose to 4.7%.
Manufacturing sector employment hit a record low at 3.24 million.
Analysts expect UK Bank of England to raise interest rates this year due to economic factors.

Meanwhile, the benefit claimant total fell 11,000 to 813,200 last month.
Throughout 2004, the number of people in work increased by 296,000 to 28.52 million - the highest figure since records began in 1971.
The apparent discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economically inactive.
smollm:1.7b: The UK's jobless total rose for the second month in a row in December 2004.
The number of people out of work increased by 32,000 to 1.41 million, while the number of people in employment rose by 90,000 to 28.52 million.
Average earnings also rose by 4.3% in the year to December up from November's 4.2%.
The benefit claimant total fell by 11,000 to 813,200 last month.
Throughout 2004, the number of people in work increased by 296,000 to 28.52 million - the highest figure since records began in 1971.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK's unemployment rose by 32,000 in December, reaching 1.41 million out of work, while employment decreased by 90,000 during the past three months.
Earnings averaged a 4.3% increase compared to last month, though benefits claimants fell by 11,000.
The working population grew by over 296,000 since records began in 1971, with economically inactive people decreasing.
Unemployment rose slightly to 4.7%, but it's still the lowest in the world.
Manufacturing jobs fell by 104,000 last quarter, pushing the sector to a record low of 3.24 million jobs.
Analysts predict BoE will raise rates due to rising unemployment despite more people in work.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK jobless total rose for the second month in a row in December, rising 32,000 to 1.41 million.
The average earnings rose by 4.3% in the year to December up from November's 4.2%, and the benefit claimant total fell 11,000 to 813,200 last month.
According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), there was an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economicly inactive.

The apparent discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economicly inactive, with more people being in work but the manufacturing sector suffering as there were 104,000 workers axed during the last quarter of 2004.
Despite more people being in work, the manufacturing sector suffered and the Bank of England will likely raise rates this year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK's jobless total rose for the second month in a row in December, according to official figures.
The number of people out of work rose by 32,000 to 1.41 million in the last three months of 2004, even as 90,000 more people were in employment.
Average earnings increased by 4.3% in the year to December up from November's 4.2%.
The benefit claimant total fell 11,000 to 813,200 last month.
Throughout 2004, the number of people in work increased by 296,000 to 28.52 million - the highest figure since records began in 1971.
The apparent discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economically inactive.
While the UK's jobless rate rose to 4.7% from 4.6%, the rate still remains one of the lowest in the world, compared with 12.1% in Germany, 10.4% in Spain and 9.7% in France.

But despite more people being in work, the manufacturing sector continued to suffer, with 104,000 workers axed during the last quarter of 2004 - pushing employment in the sector to a record low of 3.24 million by the end of last year.
The figures prompted some analysts to forecast that the Bank of England will almost certainly raise rates this year.
Marc Ostwald, a strategist at Monument Securities told Reuters that while no immediate market impact could be expected, "it is enough to underline that they (the BoE) will be more hawkish on rates".

hermes3:3b: UK jobless rises for 2nd month in December, total up to 1.41m; employment increases by 90k but average earnings rise by 4.3%.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK's jobless total increased for the second month in a row in December, reaching 1.41 million.
Unemployment rose 32,000 from the previous month, while employment increased by 90,000 to a record 28.52 million.
The discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economically inactive.
Despite more people being employed, the manufacturing sector still suffered, with 104,000 workers being laid off in the last quarter of 2004.
This decline pushed employment in the sector to a record low of 3.24 million by the end of the year.
The figures have led some analysts to predict that the Bank of England will likely raise interest rates this year.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK jobless total rises for the second month in a row in December, with a 1 million increase to 1.8 million over three months (4.7% rise in annual earnings).
Meanwhile, the benefit claimant total fell and the number of people in work increased.
The discrepancy between rising unemployment and record numbers in work can be explained by an increase in the working population and a fall in those who are economically inactive.
Despite more people being in work, the manufacturing sector continues to suffer with 1 million jobs lost during Q4 (record low employment at 3 million).
Bank of England may raise rates due to these figures.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In December 2004, the UK's jobless total increased by 32,000 to 1.41 million, despite a net gain of 90,000 jobs, indicating an expansion in the working population and a decline in economically inactive individuals.
This led to a rise in the unemployment rate to 4.7% from 4.6%.
Despite this, overall employment numbers reached a record high of 28.52 million, reflecting a significant increase from 1971.
The manufacturing sector suffered, with 104,000 job losses by year-end.
Analysts predict the Bank of England will likely raise interest rates due to these trends, signaling a more hawkish stance on monetary policy.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK's jobless total rose by 32,000 to 1.41 million in the last three months of 2004, despite 90,000 more people gaining employment.
Average earnings increased by 4.3% in the year to December, while benefit claimants fell by 11,000 to 813,200.
The total number of people in work reached a record 28.52 million.
The rise in unemployment alongside record employment is attributed to an increasing workforce and fewer economically inactive individuals.
The jobless rate rose slightly to 4.7% but remained low compared to other European countries.
However, the manufacturing sector continued to decline, losing 104,000 jobs, bringing employment in the sector to a record low of 3.24 million.
Analysts predict the Bank of England may raise interest rates in response.
